Fri, Oct 23, 2015, 14:24 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 6 mins Cafe with 'offensive' name sees surge in sales following legal threat By Lauren Davidson | Telegraph â€“ 11 minutes ago KC-ZK15-c.NYB 0.00 
The Bermondsey Street coffee shop's owner is concerned that the business will lose sales once the sign is removed 
A rudely-named coffee shop in south east London has seen a surge in sales since a legal order to remove its sign spread on social media earlier this week. 
Adrian Jones, the owner of F***offee, said that business has picked up by 20pc in the last two days as curious coffee drinkers and fans of the controversial name stopped by to support the cafe. 
The Bermondsey Street coffee shop received a letter from its landlord's lawyers demanding the removal of its "offensive" sign or face further legal action or the forfeiture of its lease. 
Mr Jones said the sign will be gone by the deadline on Tuesday, October 27. 
"We have to take it down, unfortunately," he told the Telegraph. "My solicitor said we haven't got a leg to stand on." 
A petition of support for the coffee shop and for "the return of a sense of humour to the UK" gathered 209 signatures within 24 hours of being created. 
Mr Jones, who also owns Brick Lane Coffee in Shoreditch and Goswell Road Coffee (NYBOT: KC-ZK15-c.NYB - news ) in Finsbury, said he has not yet decided on a new name. 
The sign was first erected about a year and a half ago when Mr Jones texted the idea to a worker following a bottle of wine while on holiday. 
"I didn't have any internet in France for two weeks, and when I got back all hell had broken loose," he said. 
The name had an immediate effect, boosting sales by 20pc and prompting the business to hire two more employees. 
Mr Jones said he is worried that sales will slump once the coffee shop , which also makes money from selling mugs with crude jokes, loses its controversial name. 
"We're right across the road from the White Cube gallery," Mr Jones said. "There are full frontal naked pictures of Tracey Emin that you can see from the road." 
However he said he understood why the sign had offended some people and said all "it was all a bit of fun, we knew it would go a wild."
